sessions.description: Keynote
sessions.title: Keynote

sessions.description: Jetpack Compose was announced at Google I/O and the team has been hard at work ever since. This talk introduces Compose to new audiences, including what the project is and how it is taking shape. The talk also updates people who already know about Jetpack Compose, including how the project has evolved.
sessions.title: What's New in Jetpack Compose

sessions.description:
With Android making its way to new form factors, and OEM’s pushing the boundaries with new technology, it’s time to take a look at what these environments bring to you and your users. It’s crucial that your developer workflow accounts for resizability, new display sizes and aspect ratios, multi display, and app continuity to provide your users the best experience no matter where they are. The days of taking the easy road with screenOrientation="portrait" are quickly coming to an end. 

In this talk we discuss the challenges faced when looking to support Android on various platforms, and how to make sure that you’re providing a great experience on all of these form-factors. You will leave this talk with an actionable checklist that helps stabilize your app and user experience on any device.
sessions.title: Android at Large: How to Bring Optimized Experiences to the Big Screen

sessions.description: Work at your own pace from a list of codelabs covering a wide variety of Android topics, from Android Jetpack to Android 10.
sessions.title: Open Codelabs

sessions.description: Room offers type-safe, easy persistence without the boilerplate—but we didn’t stop there! In Room 2.2 we’ve added several highly requested features: better support for relationships, integration with Kotlin Flows, pre-packaged databases, partial entities, schema default values and faster build speed. In this talk, you’ll learn about these features and how using them in your app will enable more advanced functionality and require less code to write and maintain.
sessions.title: What’s new in Room

sessions.description: Learn what’s new with CameraX since its alpha launch at Google I/O this year, and hear about learnings from teams at Google who have been using CameraX in their apps.
sessions.title: What's New with CameraX

sessions.description:
Get an overview of what’s new for Android studio design tools for Android app developers including demos: New Layout inspector, New Motion Editor, Navigation Editor, Resource management improvements, Marble improvements.

This talk covers the Motion Layout as well as the new Motion Layout Editor, including an overview of new features, live creation of animations using the editor, and tips and tricks.
sessions.title: What's New in Android Studio Design Tools

sessions.description: Join us for a live recording of an ADB podcast episode, with hosts Tor, Chet, and Romain, plus the chance for live Q&A from the audience.
sessions.title: ADB Live

sessions.description: Learn the basics of Jetpack Compose, Android's new Kotlin-based declarative toolkit for building UI.
sessions.title: Jetpack Compose Codelab

sessions.description:
To aid developers with creating immersive experiences, Android 10 adds new system navigation models that allow apps to take over more of the user's screen.

This talk looks at how apps should work with the new gesture navigation, and ways to mitigate gesture conflicts. We also look at how to update apps to go edge to edge, drawing behind the system bars to create an immersive experience for users.
sessions.title: Going Edge-to-Edge with Gesture Navigation

sessions.description: Android Lint allows teams to automate the enforcement of best practices, reducing the amount of time spent on trivial code review feedback and improving overall code health. This talk teaches the basics of writing a custom Lint rule, including how to test and distribute custom Lint rules for your own team.
sessions.title: Coding in Style: Static Analysis with Custom Lint Rules

sessions.description: Gradle’s API for task inputs, outputs, and wiring has changed significantly over the last couple of years. In this session we will review the current best practices and how they fit with new upcoming APIs for the Android Gradle Plugin
sessions.title: DSL and APIs in Android Gradle Plugin

sessions.description: Work at your own pace from a list of codelabs covering a wide variety of Android topics, from Android Jetpack to Android 10.
sessions.title: Open Codelabs

sessions.description: Learn more about WorkManager, the Jetpack library for background processing. This talk will introduce intermediate and advanced concepts to address common questions, gotchas, and issues you might see when you deploy to a large ecosystem of users and devices.
sessions.title: WorkManager: Beyond the Basics

sessions.description: It's easy to forget about performance until users complain, but you can prevent a bad user experience by catching regressions in CI. We'll explore why variance makes regression detection difficult, and strategies we use while writing Jetpack libraries. We'll review the new Jetpack Benchmark library, and how to use it to measure hot code paths, from RecyclerView scrolling to database queries.
sessions.title: Fighting Regressions with Benchmarks in CI

sessions.description: In this session we will provide updates and demos on new developments & features in Android Studio and how the tools can integrate into your app development workflow.
sessions.title: What's New in Android Studio

sessions.description: The Android TV platform is on a great momentum, it has grown 2x year over year and has over 4,000 apps in its ecosystem. This presentation will help you be successful in engaging the audience with your app with insight into Android TV integrations, success metrics, and lessons learned along the way.
sessions.title: Android TV: Best Practices for Engaging Apps

sessions.description: Learn the basics of MotionLayout with guidance from its authors and how to use it to build rich animations in your app.
sessions.title: MotionLayout Codelab

sessions.description: We'll take a deep dive into the reality of migrating to AndroidX! We'll be providing rationale to migrate soon, setting expectations appropriately, and recommending a process for executing the migration as smoothly as possible.
sessions.title: Migrating to AndroidX: The Time Is Right

sessions.description: With new Android Automotive OS based infotainment systems that are built directly into cars, this talk focuses on how to build new apps or adapt existing Android Auto apps to Android Automotive OS. It walks you through how to design, develop, publish, and distribute your media app.
sessions.title: How to Build Media Apps for Cars

sessions.description: This talk details various techniques employed by the Filament rendering engine to deliver high performance on Android devices: CPU cache-friendly programming, multi-threaded job system to saturate cores, dynamic resolution, frame skipping, doing shader computations in half-floats, how to use small float formats for textures, writing SIMD and optimization-friendly C++ code, and more.
sessions.title: High Performance (Graphics) Programming

sessions.description:
In the past few years, we have introduced new features into Google Play, that enable users to discover and purchase items and subscriptions in many new ways, from inside and outside the app.

Developers who have adopted these changes in their apps have seen improvements in user experience, and with it, substantial growth in revenue. However, integrating these features into an app or game requires a fundamental change in which you think about how purchases are made and consumed.

In this session, we will take a deep dive into designing for Purchase Anywhere. We will talk about promotions, subscribe-and-install, cash purchases and pending transactions, and remote purchase approvals.

All app and game developers using Google Play Billing are welcome to attend.
sessions.title: Google Play Billing: The “Purchase Anywhere” Paradigm Shift

sessions.description: Build an app that stores a list of words in a Room database and displays the list in a RecyclerView, all implemented using our recommended architecture using the Android Jetpack Architecture Components.
sessions.title: Room with a View Codelab

sessions.description: Learn from a panel of experts from the Android platform engineering team, where they will answer your questions - live.
sessions.title: Android Fireside Chat

sessions.description: Google Play Protect is constantly reviewing apps and warning users when we discover behavior that meets our MUwS (Mobile Unwanted Software) and PHA (Potentially Harmful App) policies. In this talk, we demystify this review process. We also share insights and examples of common pitfalls that cause "good" developers to run afoul of these policies.
sessions.title: Why Does Google Think My App Is Harmful?

sessions.description: Plan overview and best practice guide to the new storage model in Android 10 and 11.
sessions.title: Preparing for Scoped Storage in Android 11

sessions.description:
With app bundles and dynamic delivery, developers now have the option to make parts of their apps available based on various user states or even on-demand at runtime. This is a big departure from the single-APK world, and we've heard loud and clear that you would like to see more support for migrating to this new model.

During this session, we will announce new tools and libraries that address some of the developer feedback that we've been gathering since the original launch. You can expect a deep dive on testing dynamic feature modules, a simplified on-demand installation API using Jetpack and Kotlin, and a new way to manage dependencies between multiple modules.
sessions.title: Navigating Your Way Around Customizable Delivery

sessions.description: Learn the basics of Jetpack Compose, Android's new Kotlin-based declarative toolkit for building UI.
sessions.title: Jetpack Compose Codelab

sessions.description:
So exactly how hard is it to find a performance benefit,, anyway? And can implement Kotlin really impact your performance? How many dex files is the best number of dex files? Is it OK to allocate short-lived objects? Is object pooling a good thing? Are enums still not OK? Those are the kinds of questions, myths and urban legends that are put to the test in this humorous series that seeks to find out which ART myths are true and which are not.

(Please don't publish this paragraph externally as it is literally the premise for Mythbusters the TV show that I warped with performance questions)
sessions.title: ART: Performance MythBusters

sessions.description:
- Advanced Haptics: The When, What, and How of New Haptic APIs
 - Adopt wide color gamut
 - What's New in C++/Native Support in Android Studio
 - Turning the Page: Migrating to ViewPager2
 - Testing coroutines on Android
sessions.title: Lightning Talks

sessions.description:
Strategies for data encryption on Android using Jetpack Security, key takeaways: learn to encrypt data safely on device and use the AndroidKeyStore.

1. Outline the challenges with data-at-rest encryption.
2. Best practices for data encryption and key management.
3. Deep dive into why and how Jetpack Security library was built.
sessions.title: Secure Your Data - Deep Dive into Encryption and Security

sessions.description: Learn how to create a camera app that uses CameraX to show a viewfinder, take photos and analyze an image stream from the camera.
sessions.title: CameraX Codelab

sessions.description: Dagger has become the recommended way to do Dependency Injection on Android.  However, there are many ways to use Dagger! Come hear why we recommend Dagger, best practices including recommended setup in multi-module projects and what plans we have to improve Dagger in Android so that you can create a solid, extensible solution for managing dependencies in your app that scales to large projects.
sessions.title: An opinionated guide to Dependency Injection on Android

sessions.description: Profilers are a powerful tool in a developer's arsenal, but working with performance data can be intimidating at times. This session demystifies the profilers in Android Studio, discussing how to read and make use of data from memory heap dumps and CPU recordings to help you optimize the performance of your app.
sessions.title: Demystify the Data in Android Studio Profilers

sessions.description: Work at your own pace from a list of codelabs covering a wide variety of Android topics, from Android Jetpack to Android 10.
sessions.title: Open Codelabs

sessions.description: This talk dives into some of the details of how the R8 application shrinker shrinks apps to make it easier for developers to use R8.
sessions.title: Shrinking Your App with R8

sessions.description: In this intermediate level talk, you’ll learn about accessibility using real world examples. You’ll find out about accessibility in framework and androidX code, and learn about support for accessibility in Android widgets. Along the way, you’ll discover good patterns that can make your UIs shine for accessibility.
sessions.title: Making Accessibility

sessions.description: Work at your own pace from a list of codelabs covering a wide variety of Android topics, from Android Jetpack to Android 10.
sessions.title: Open Codelabs

sessions.description: Fragments were one of the first APIs unbundled from the Android framework and have evolved significantly since their introduction. We'll be talking though the origins of Fragments, how our more recent changes have made them easier to work with, and give a glimpse into where Fragments are going and their place in 2019 and beyond.
sessions.title: Fragments: Past, Present, and Future

sessions.description:
- Gaming Lightning Talk
 - Better Application Quality with Android GSI
 - Pick Your USB Cables Wisely
sessions.title: Lightning Talks

sessions.description: Get started with Android testing by writing features and tests for a modern real-world Android application.
sessions.title: Testing Codelab

sessions.description:
The Android theming system is powerful but easy to misuse. Proper use of it can make your layouts easier to maintain and support dark themes or implement material theming to systematically customize Material Design to better reflect your product’s brand.

This talk will start with a crash course in themes and styles and how to apply styling throughout your app while isolating theme dependent resources. We’ll then walk through applied examples of using the styling system to build material themed apps and dark themes.
sessions.title: Developing Themes with Style

sessions.description: The Vitals section of the Play Console contains a huge amount of information about the health of developers' apps in the wild: crashes, ANRs, benchmarks against their peers' performance, and so on. This talk will provide an in-depth look at best practices for using Vitals to detect, debug and fix problems with apps. Developers will leave with a better understanding of what Android Vitals is, and how to use it to improve the real-world performance of their apps.
sessions.title: Vitals Masterclass: monitoring and improving real-world stability and performance

sessions.description: Level up your debugging skills! We all spend so much time in the debugger, so this session will teach you about some of the powerful debugging features available in Android Studio. This talk should appeal to all, from beginners to experts and everybody in between. No matter your level, you'll take away something to help you chase bugs more effectively using Android Studio.
sessions.title: Android Studio: Debugging Tips n' Tricks

sessions.description: Play's In-app updates API lets you prompt users to update your app while they are using the app, launched at Google I/O this year. In this talk we will review what's new since then and explore ways that in-app updates can be used by your app.
sessions.title: In-App Updates

sessions.description: Work at your own pace from a list of codelabs covering a wide variety of Android topics, from Android Jetpack to Android 10.
sessions.title: Open Codelabs

sessions.description:
Kotlin is awesome and you want to write all your code in it, but what about the thousands of lines of code already written in the Java programming language? Or ,maybe you have a library or project that is written in Java and already has been used in so many Kotlin or Java projects.

In this talk, we will look at the best practices for writing Kotlin  and Java code that works so seamlessly from the other that the only way to what language its written in is to look at the source code.
sessions.title: Java❤️ Kotlin, Happy Together 🎵

sessions.description: TensorFlow Lite has been difficult to use, requiring developers to convert typed objects into ByteArray and decode the output from ByteArray. TFLite Support Library is designed to simplify this and enable developers to use common typed objects. In this session, we will go through this new tool as well as best practices related to model acceleration through NNAPI on-device.
sessions.title: Integrating TensorFlow Lite model with your app

sessions.description: This talk will provide a deep dive into the new tooling the framework team has been working to allow better understanding permission usage for your app. We will provide specifics around mechanisms for attributing permissions for features in the app which in addition to the tooling to track access can provide insights into private data use. This would enable apps to limit their private data use. We will also present planned permission changes.
sessions.title: Permission Tooling and Changes

sessions.description:
- Performance Analysis Using Systrace
 - Supercharge Sharing to your App
 - The Digital Wellbeing Opportunity
 - Wait, There Is a UX Team On Android Studio?
 - 64-Bit Tips and Tricks
sessions.title: Lightning Talks

sessions.description: This talk will talk about the benefits of a declarative reactive UI system and how it applies to real problems that Android developers have today. Today Android XML Layouts are declarative but static, meaning all dynamic aspects of the UI must be done programmatically in an imperative style. The result of this is that many UIs have strong but implicit coupling between UI Logic and their corresponding UI Layouts. This talk will show alternative architectures that move the coupling from implicit to explicit, and in the process, make things simpler, easier to navigate, and more understandable
sessions.title: From Implicit to Explicit: Coupling of UI and UI Logic on Android

sessions.description:
There’s a direct correlation between a reliable, effortless purchase experience and resulting revenues. Designing for quality is even more important as the way users discover and purchase your one-time products and subscriptions changes.

In this session, we’ll show how you can increase purchase reliability and performance, while preparing for the future of “Purchase Anywhere”. We’ll cover RTDN, Play Developer APIs, refunded purchases, and frictionless subscriptions. We’ll show how Billing Library 2 makes updates easy and improves performance, as well as how to migrate from AIDL and Billing Library 1 before the deadline.
sessions.title: Google Play Billing: Required Updates and New Functionality

sessions.description: LiveData is a simple lifecycle-aware observable, designed for making UIs that react to changes safely and efficiently. It can be used beyond View↔️ViewModel communications and even components like Room support it. However, there's a risk of overuse, especially when dealing with multiple threads. The solution? Instead of expanding its features, LiveData now works seamlessly with Kotlin's coroutines. In this talk, we'll cover the new "liveData" coroutine builder, showing when and how to use it and testing patterns and antipatterns to make clean, efficient, and solid reactive UIs.
sessions.title: LiveData with Coroutines and Flow

sessions.description: Apps using Foreground Services to get foreground privileges such as the ability to access location or record audio/video would need to make their intentions more explicit. We started with such restrictions in Android Q and are continuing to add more restrictions to give users the privacy they expect.
sessions.title: Foreground Service Types and Permissions

00757d1f-2171-5169-91e8-82846c4861c0.bio: Fabien Sanglard is a Software Engineer at Google where he has worked on Android Graphic Compositor and Android Studio. He enjoys writing about 90s games on fabiensanglard.net and in his Game Engine books. Fabien has a MSCS from Grenoble University.
00757d1f-2171-5169-91e8-82846c4861c0.name: Fabien Sanglard

03f440c4-7081-5656-bf48-94b4e69a6680.bio: Interaction Designer @ Google crafting meaningful experiences for Android Developer Tools
03f440c4-7081-5656-bf48-94b4e69a6680.name: Paris Hsu

0582b596-637b-50eb-bd0b-a3a2e5fdac69.bio: David Herman is currently leading an effort to improve the Android Data Binding integration in Android Studio, although he previously worked with the Profiler Tools team for several years.
0582b596-637b-50eb-bd0b-a3a2e5fdac69.name: David Herman

083b3363-5d60-5797-a2cf-e3b9fb799a23.bio: Romain manages the Android Toolkit team, who responsibilities include Jetpack, Jetpack Compose and the UI Toolkit. He also sometimes contributes code to Filament, a 3D real-time rendering engine.
083b3363-5d60-5797-a2cf-e3b9fb799a23.name: Romain Guy

0b6cac79-2636-551a-9402-75729192abb3.bio: Christoffer Quist Adamsen is a Software Engineer on the Android Compilers team working on shrinking Android applications. Prior to working at Google, he was a PhD student in the Programming Languages research group at Aarhus University, Denmark.
0b6cac79-2636-551a-9402-75729192abb3.name: Christoffer Quist Adamsen

0c0c4e7f-c533-5a3a-911a-682413e24d1e.bio: I run the release of Jetpack libraries. I joined the Android Team over a year and been working ever since to improve the Developer Experience for Jetpack!
0c0c4e7f-c533-5a3a-911a-682413e24d1e.name: Nick Anthony

0df8e25b-d5b3-5ebb-8c00-c6c1a121cf9d.bio: Wojtek works on the Android Developer Relations team, supporting developers in building great apps using Kotlin, Android Studio and Play.
0df8e25b-d5b3-5ebb-8c00-c6c1a121cf9d.name: Wojtek Kaliciński

197b9266-a86c-5eb4-bead-2ca3e932e93b.bio: James' mission is to make apps and games on the Play Store as high quality as they can be, and to open the batting for England. He is aware that he is unlikely to achieve both.
197b9266-a86c-5eb4-bead-2ca3e932e93b.name: James Heather

1f0ab9fa-afdd-58cb-9816-9d9303ac81c6.bio: Daniel is a Puerto Rican native currently working on the Android Toolkit team at Google. He is passionate about developing open source libraries that increase developer happiness and productivity. He also likes video games, like a lot.
1f0ab9fa-afdd-58cb-9816-9d9303ac81c6.name: Daniel Santiago Rivera

282ccd67-3719-5d1d-8db3-0e22b84d8607.bio: Iliyan has been with Android from the very beginning.  He leads the Linux core of the OS and is in charge of Project Treble.  When not obsessing about Linux and updatability, he spends his time promoting Rust and WebAssembly to anyone within earshot.
282ccd67-3719-5d1d-8db3-0e22b84d8607.name: Iliyan Malchev

2d3df339-5aff-5215-9ea3-3ba7eb61e676.bio: Software Engineer on the Android Toolkit team
2d3df339-5aff-5215-9ea3-3ba7eb61e676.name: Rahul Ravikumar

2dd4dd15-0fd4-5db1-84c7-e4af7b598995.bio: Yigit leads the Architecture Components for Android, focusing on the developer experience and dreams of making app development easy.  He received his B.S. in Computer Engineering from Middle East Technical University / Turkey.
2dd4dd15-0fd4-5db1-84c7-e4af7b598995.name: Yigit Boyar

33a0b336-191e-59cb-a5a7-8eae012e42bd.bio: Android developer advocate, working on Android Studio, Jetpack Compose, User Privacy and Kotlin, based in the UK
33a0b336-191e-59cb-a5a7-8eae012e42bd.name: Yacine Rezgui

3aac0967-141a-567f-a958-878087025402.bio: Caren is an Engineer on the Android Developer Relations team, where she works to help make developer lives easier. Before that she worked at various startups ranging from camera apps to smart ovens.
3aac0967-141a-567f-a958-878087025402.name: Caren Chang

3b58cc6e-2911-5512-ade4-03c4d05a39e9.bio: Tor Norbye is the engineering director for Android Studio. Prior to joining Google in 2010 he worked for 14 years at Sun Microsystems, also on developer tools. He holds a master's degree in computer science from Stanford University.
3b58cc6e-2911-5512-ade4-03c4d05a39e9.name: Tor Norbye

3c919315-9895-55f0-98e6-1a774e625557.bio: Jason is a product manager focused on improving the developer experience on Google Play.  Prior to this, Jason worked on YouTube Ads and Google Chrome.  Jason has a BS from Yale University.
3c919315-9895-55f0-98e6-1a774e625557.name: Jason Karl Liu

3d9e94c1-082b-5a18-bf40-f800fec3f5b0.bio: I am an software engineer working on Android Studio C++ support.
3d9e94c1-082b-5a18-bf40-f800fec3f5b0.name: Tianyu Geng

412d63b4-705b-5cb1-87c5-887a55457d78.bio: Engineer on the Android Accessibility Team
412d63b4-705b-5cb1-87c5-887a55457d78.name: Qasid Sadiq

45de12e0-144e-570a-af8a-81a52e63d782.bio:
Ben enables developers to ship smaller apps to users.
Come and talk with him about modularization, dynamic features and navigating them.
He also coordinates the Android GDE program.
45de12e0-144e-570a-af8a-81a52e63d782.name: Ben Weiss

4838c594-7af9-54ff-9a4b-e78d251bc9be.bio: Dom is the product manager for the Android App Bundle and Dynamic Delivery, which enable next generation app publishing and distribution on Google Play.
4838c594-7af9-54ff-9a4b-e78d251bc9be.name: Dom Elliott

4a3ad12e-d660-5d42-bcbb-940ea4e16efb.bio: Please provide a short bio that will be used on the event website (be sure not to include any project names or products that are unreleased)
4a3ad12e-d660-5d42-bcbb-940ea4e16efb.name: Please provide your full name (this is how it will appear on the event website)

4b6567d1-e3da-56c4-9f9c-43189c2af8e7.bio: I believe that the best way to understand how something works is to take it apart (and possibly put it back together at the end). My children share this belief, which results in a lot of broken toys in our house!
4b6567d1-e3da-56c4-9f9c-43189c2af8e7.name: Pietro Maggi

558bc577-8151-5918-b68f-98b360a60e39.bio: Jose is a Developer Relations Engineer at Google where he focuses on architecture and testing. He writes documentation, codelabs, articles, samples and does outreach for topics like Data Binding, Lifecycles, Navigation, LiveData and coroutines.
558bc577-8151-5918-b68f-98b360a60e39.name: Jose Alcérreca

5bbb6312-0604-5927-9b71-089c01fdaf04.bio: Clara is one of the leads behind Jetpack Compose. She leads the Android Toolkit team in London and has been part of the Toolkit team for several years, working on Text and Widgets.
5bbb6312-0604-5927-9b71-089c01fdaf04.name: Clara Bayarri

5c6a8332-7b55-564d-a90c-2612963c64c7.bio: Manuel is an Android Developer in the Developer Relations team at Google where he works to help other developers succeed.
5c6a8332-7b55-564d-a90c-2612963c64c7.name: Manuel Vivo

5e59b748-c72d-546d-abbe-ed96d9c5b9c9.bio: Chris is the UX Design Lead for Android Developer tools. He has a passion for creating elegant developer experiences. Prior to Google, he worked on VS Code and Hololens at Microsoft.
5e59b748-c72d-546d-abbe-ed96d9c5b9c9.name: Chris Sinco

5e8a7e1c-3b30-58ff-8bde-9370a6312d46.bio: Software Engineer on Google Play. Working on: Android App Bundle, Dynamic Apps, In App Updates, PlayCore library.
5e8a7e1c-3b30-58ff-8bde-9370a6312d46.name: Alessandro Dovis

60456bcc-1c8c-5412-b689-b66689e756bc.bio: Tiem is an Android Developer Programs Engineer focusing on Kotlin, Jetpack, and the Sunflower open source Android app. Prior to Google, he worked at Venmo and other startups in the San Francisco Bay Area.
60456bcc-1c8c-5412-b689-b66689e756bc.name: Tiem Song

61738f00-e3a8-516a-a4d1-7d552f779c2e.bio: Rony is a Quantitative UX Researcher working on Digital Wellbeing. While at work, he likes to think about the relationship between technology and sleep. While at home, he likes to watch tv, eat brunch, and hangout with his friends.
61738f00-e3a8-516a-a4d1-7d552f779c2e.name: Rony Patel

63cac32a-c6a8-5168-8223-9520b438522b.bio: Kenneth Ford is a Developer Advocate at Google where he's spent most of his time helping developers bring better experiences to different Android form factors including foldables, tablets, and Chrome OS.
63cac32a-c6a8-5168-8223-9520b438522b.name: Kenneth Ford

63d139dd-e0bd-5de5-ba26-fc5ff2a3b27e.bio: Dustin is a software engineer on the Android Toolkit team working on Architecture Components.
63d139dd-e0bd-5de5-ba26-fc5ff2a3b27e.name: Dustin Lam

67f64602-596f-5919-89e1-6234945167a9.bio: Rohan is a product manager at Google on the Android System UI team, with prior experience working with Android development on the Android Gmail team.
67f64602-596f-5919-89e1-6234945167a9.name: Rohan Shah

687edff2-ef0d-50d5-93e0-1ca18b8033d9.bio: Nicolas works on the Android Studio Design Tools and the ConstraintLayout library at Google
687edff2-ef0d-50d5-93e0-1ca18b8033d9.name: Nicolas Roard

6e835ff2-a4b6-5897-a07c-49b37d11f146.bio: Jeremy is a software engineer on the Android Toolkit team, working on Activity, Fragments, and Navigation.  Jeremy has a MS in Software Engineering from the University of Washington at Bothell and a BS in Software Engineering from Auburn University.
6e835ff2-a4b6-5897-a07c-49b37d11f146.name: Jeremy Woods

709c6371-7802-5b4a-895c-8530095ae50f.bio: Stephanie joined Google in 2012 and is Senior Director of Developer PM, DevRel and UX for Android. She previously worked on Google’s Search & Ads businesses, as well as a range of developer tools used by Google employees internally. Prior to Google, she was at AWS where she led the product management team for Storage, including Amazon S3. Before AWS, she spent 10 years working on Visual Studio and developer tools. Stephanie graduated with honors from Brown University where she was a graduation speaker and Royce Fellow.
709c6371-7802-5b4a-895c-8530095ae50f.name: Stephanie Cuthbertson

7cc26780-82df-5657-9dba-c4367758a968.bio: Alec is a reverse engineer with Android Security, working on fighting malware in the Android ecosystem.
7cc26780-82df-5657-9dba-c4367758a968.name: Alec Guertin

81624c40-95a2-5327-a3a6-a4d31c8ef77a.bio: Justin Nieto is a Georgia Tech math-major-turned-software-engineer. His main focus is to provide Android Studio support for Google's first-party app developers, but he has also worked on externally-visible features like manifest merging.
81624c40-95a2-5327-a3a6-a4d31c8ef77a.name: Justin Nieto

81d88793-feab-5977-a245-0dcaffbc7283.bio: Yi Yang is a software engineer on the Android Studio team working on profilers.
81d88793-feab-5977-a245-0dcaffbc7283.name: Yi Yang

83b1fdf1-726e-5199-b246-34e35424ecb8.bio: Jamal Eason is a product manager on Android Studio. Prior to Google, he worked on developer tools at Intel, worked as a product manager at a startup, and was an officer in the US Army. He earned a BS in computer science from USMA and a MBA from HBS.
83b1fdf1-726e-5199-b246-34e35424ecb8.name: Jamal Eason

8aa993f1-66c4-5eba-858e-30af7afd7129.bio: Alan is a technical lead on the Android Toolkit team responsible for Jetpack library policies, releases, and development workflow.
8aa993f1-66c4-5eba-858e-30af7afd7129.name: Alan Viverette

8b5afe26-8362-59c6-bb1a-364251c8dcca.bio: Scott is an Associate Product Manager working on Android Studio and Android Toolkit. As a Product Manager, Scott is responsible for the Android animation developer experience and has worked on projects like MotionLayout and Jetpack Compose animation.
8b5afe26-8362-59c6-bb1a-364251c8dcca.name: Scott Swarthout

8d1b507a-1bf4-5f4a-aec7-b4a0a9f9ecbd.bio: Chris is an engineer working in Android Developer Relations at Google. He likes to make pixels dance.
8d1b507a-1bf4-5f4a-aec7-b4a0a9f9ecbd.name: Chris Banes

8e8f2ed4-2c48-57b3-8fb4-2b3595ec7c1d.bio: Amrit Sanjeev works as a developer advocate in the partner developer relations team and works with partners in India. He was the first Android GDE from India and actively participates in developer communities in India.
8e8f2ed4-2c48-57b3-8fb4-2b3595ec7c1d.name: Amrit Sanjeev

a028e287-20e2-5bec-a5e8-85338e4e1900.bio: Oscar is a Developer Advocate based in Tokyo, working with game developers in East Asia, to ensure they make the best games, using the best technology, offering the best developer experience, to delight players over the world.
a028e287-20e2-5bec-a5e8-85338e4e1900.name: Oscar Rodriguez

a0c318cc-6785-5449-bb93-d29ee014fd55.bio: Florina is helping developers build beautiful, clean and testable apps. She has been working with Android for 8 years, previous work covering news at upday, payment solutions at payleven and navigation services at Garmin.
a0c318cc-6785-5449-bb93-d29ee014fd55.name: Florina Muntenescu

a7393afd-e92d-57d5-95d9-df27a59a212d.bio: Diana is a Product Manager on Android Developer where she focuses on the Android Runtime (ART), App Compatibility & device fragmentation, and the NDK. Prior to joining Google, she worked on web and mobile apps at an enterprise SAAS company.
a7393afd-e92d-57d5-95d9-df27a59a212d.name: Diana Wong

ab5b433b-3376-5b04-89ad-cf88541abad1.bio: Tyler is a designer, engineer, artist and musician. Currently he works on Wear OS at Google, previously at a smartwatch startup and his own wearables startup DrumPants. He specializes in wearables, assistive technology and accessibility, and haptics.
ab5b433b-3376-5b04-89ad-cf88541abad1.name: Tyler Freeman

aceb3fdf-e4cf-5510-85fe-1da0d1783b75.bio: Preethi is a User Experience Researcher on the Android Platform and Tools team at Google. She has a PhD in Human-Computer Interaction from Indiana University and a Masters in Computer Science from Miami University.
aceb3fdf-e4cf-5510-85fe-1da0d1783b75.name: Preethi Srinivas

c0576cf9-a968-538e-9682-056b8fb079bd.bio: Dan is a Product Manager responsible for the Media, Messaging and App experience on Android Auto. He has a Bachelors degree in Software Engineering from the Rochester Institute of Technology
c0576cf9-a968-538e-9682-056b8fb079bd.name: Dan Larsen

c86f2bc1-461e-561b-acf5-4035dca4be83.bio: Xavier is a lead for the Android Studio group, with a focus on Build, and emulator. He joined Google in 2007 and has worked on developer tools for Android since then.
c86f2bc1-461e-561b-acf5-4035dca4be83.name: Xavier Ducrohet

c8cf99cc-a171-5866-9e66-4e59c6497b44.bio: Helping devs make their apps awesome: specializing in size-reduction, instant apps, and app modularization.
c8cf99cc-a171-5866-9e66-4e59c6497b44.name: Udam Singh Saini

ccf9955e-9218-5462-9c96-52359acc5a16.bio: Claire is an engineering friendly designer/researcher who has supported Android haptics since Nougat. Claire is passionate about delivering UX inspired HW/SW specification for Android/Pixel haptics.
ccf9955e-9218-5462-9c96-52359acc5a16.name: Seungyon "Claire" Lee

cf8b8a10-7329-59c9-83fa-1f3b141a2f75.bio: Sean McQuillan is a Developer Advocate at Google. With a decade of experience at Twilio and other San Francisco startups, he is an expert at building apps that scale. Sean is passionate about using great tooling to build high quality apps quickly.
cf8b8a10-7329-59c9-83fa-1f3b141a2f75.name: Sean McQuillan

cfe2c396-8b10-5fd3-a18f-d78224a41754.bio: Ian is a software engineer on the Android Toolkit team, working on Architecture Components and Fragments. Previously, Ian worked in Android Developer Relations at Google and, before that, built Android apps at Facebook and Phunware.
cfe2c396-8b10-5fd3-a18f-d78224a41754.name: Ian Lake

d09e9c2e-3144-5a12-809e-2a0f3e35fcb0.bio: Sumir is a software engineer on the Android Toolkit team.  He works on Jetpack libraries.
d09e9c2e-3144-5a12-809e-2a0f3e35fcb0.name: Sumir Kataria

d251306a-e7b6-506b-b885-2010f6e5c3dd.bio: I work on the Android Framework on projects spanning privacy and updatability improvements
d251306a-e7b6-506b-b885-2010f6e5c3dd.name: Zim Ezeozue

d794ca78-38ad-5345-9af7-8d27e6fd4ef7.bio: Nicole is a Developer Programs Engineer at Google with a focus on privacy and Android core platform APIs. Prior to joining Google, she was a senior Android developer at Smule, and an Android lead at Funzio.
d794ca78-38ad-5345-9af7-8d27e6fd4ef7.name: Nicole Borrelli

db702933-ddcb-557c-9e24-019bab3254e1.bio: Boris is a Senior Partner Engineer at Google. Boris manages technical relations with games and apps companies. On the tech side Boris focuses on Android Performance. Boris holds M.Sc. in Computer Science and M.B.A. in Marketing.
db702933-ddcb-557c-9e24-019bab3254e1.name: Boris Farber

de0c643d-efe2-5670-b576-aa0493543ea8.bio: Murat Yener is a Developer Advocate for Android at Google. He is a code geek, open source committer, Java Champion and the author of Expert Android Studio and Professional Java EE Design Patterns books.
de0c643d-efe2-5670-b576-aa0493543ea8.name: Murat Yener

f11707d2-9ba0-5ec8-a624-35b33ea4e00f.bio: Shukang leads the profiler team in Android Studio. Prior to this, he worked on programming language indexing and compiler optimizations.
f11707d2-9ba0-5ec8-a624-35b33ea4e00f.name: Shukang Zhou

f1aa0898-bbcb-540f-97aa-e78ce78eee47.bio: Wenbo is a software engineer on the Google Nest apps team
f1aa0898-bbcb-540f-97aa-e78ce78eee47.name: Wenbo Zhu

f398c6c2-84e8-5e47-a1f9-a382c4d7f59f.bio: Carmen is on the Android Performance team at Google, focusing on memory and on-device System Tracing. She is also on the Board of Directors of Double Union, a maker space for women and nonbinary people in San Francisco.
f398c6c2-84e8-5e47-a1f9-a382c4d7f59f.name: Carmen Jackson

f6ab579b-2ea4-57da-a950-b3bdf20598b4.bio: Nick is an Android Developer Advocate at Google, focussed on helping designers and developers to understand and create beautiful UIs.
f6ab579b-2ea4-57da-a950-b3bdf20598b4.name: Nick Butcher

f8c2ed65-4d32-51ae-bf13-a6ed6b15971c.bio: Søren Gjesse is a Software Engineer who has worked on a number of compiler projects at Google including V8, Dart and now R8. Søren joined Google in 2007 and holds a masters degree in Computer Science form the University of in Denmark.
f8c2ed65-4d32-51ae-bf13-a6ed6b15971c.name: Søren Gjesse
